discussion.content: I think the answer is correct. They are not looking for the correct syntax here rather than knowing if you know what to do from the command line.
I would say NO. To remove an update, use the command wusa /uninstall /kb:2982791 /quiet and replace the KB number with the number of the update that you want to remove.

comments.content: agree with Engr, it stated "and specify the /uninstall parameter"
in the question it states to "specify the uninstall parameter" meaning the KB number of the update you want to uninstall. So it's Yes

discussion.content:
I think its NO, because they explicitly say /uninstall not uninstall parameters. The /uninstall is one direct parameter and without the others it will just display help.

When will MS stop tricking us with these stupid questions and test real knowledge. You spent more time on reverse engineering the tricks in the question then the actual question itself.

For me, the syntax is partially correct because the /kb parameter and the KB number are required to allow a complete uninstall.
Other answers are sometimes rejected for less than that :D
In another question this is one of the right choices. So it has to be right here as well.
This is partially correct, you have to specify the parameter to complete the goal.

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have a computer named Computer1 that runs Windows 10.
You test Windows updates on Computer1 before you make the updates available to other computers.
You install a quality update that conflicts with a custom device driver.
You need to remove the update from Computer1.
Solution: From an elevated command prompt, you run the wusa.exe command and specify the /uninstall parameter.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
I have found this information, therefore the correct answers are: 
-Admin Approval Mode for the Built-in Administrator account
-Only elevate executable files that are signed and validated
https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/windows-itpro-docs/blob/public/windows/security/identity-protection/user-account-control/user-account-control-security-policy-settings.md

I'm confused by this question...
Requirement say that Administrator should ALWAYS be prompted for approval. This means enabling Admin Approval Mode for Built-in administrator AND changing Behavior of the elevation prompt for administrators from "Prompt for consent for non-Windows binaries" to "Prompt for consent".

Three, not two policies needs to be changed for these requirements. Any other thoughts? Given answer is correct enough I guess.

discussion.content:
A. whoami

The whoami command displays the name of the current user, the security identifier (SID), and the group memberships for the current user. Additionally, the whoami /user command can be used to display the username and SID of the current user.

questions.question_text:
You have a computer that runs Windows 10.

You need to identify the following information:

• The name, username, and SID of the computer
• The user groups to which your user account belongs

Which command should you run?

discussion.content:
Confusing question. If you plan to access a computer via subscription you will have to manage to add the computer to the Event Log Readers. If you plan to access via action > Connect to Another Computer, then you only need to deal with firewall rules.

Assuming that we are discussing about users only, the answers should be YES YES YES.

If you are a member of the Event Log Readers from the domain, you will see any event log including security logs.

Should be:
1: NO (contoso\event log readers groups only gives you permission for the local computer)
2: NO (users can't read the security event log)
3: YES (since User1 is member of the local "event log readers" group)

Members of this group are granted permissions to read the event logs on the local computer.
https://techgenix.com/allowing-access-directory-service-event-log/
